item.title: Korean housing
item.description:
On the weekend we moved into our own home - no more hotels for a while! The apartments come with nothing, but we now have a fridge/freezer, microwave and washing machine, so we can live there. While we are waiting for the sofa bed to arrive, we are camping out Korean style (mattress on the floor) which is actually better than we expected.

Everything in the apartment is electronic which is nice, but sometimes a little difficult to work things out when they’re all in Korean! It took me half an hour to work out how to turn on the lights, and in 24 hours we haven’t managed to get hot water yet. Other things we can use the panel for include video calling the other apartments in the complex or checking the time and photo of anyone who rang the doorbell!

Most people (like us) who grew up in the suburbs with backyards to play in would probably be horrified at the idea of living in a big block of high rise apartments. But to the contrary, I’m really growing to like the idea. It means shared resources such as a gym, indoor golf, a library and several kids’ playgrounds, and building all of the apartments in one block means plenty of natural space left for everyone to enjoy. There’s definitely no shortage of space in the apartments either.

Our open plan living room with the bedrooms at the back, laundry to the left and cinema room to the right.
Shared resources within the complex means you don’t have to go far to get to the gym.
Higher living means a better view.
To make up for the lack of yard there is a balcony where you can dry your clothes (wind down rack shown above) and keep plants, as most Koreans do. The space even comes with a hose and a drain for this purpose.
The walkways are still tree lined despite the 13 buildings with a total of more than 500 apartments.
Our Korean style bed, until our sofa bed and then real bed arrive.
High rise buildings leave plenty of space for beautiful bike paths along the river and wetlands.
One of the big apartments blocks close to the river to be able to make the most of the bike / walking paths.

item.title: Seoul
item.description:
On Monday and Tuesday of the long weekend we took a quick trip to Seoul to see some traditional Korean sites and find out what the capital had to offer. Not everything was open because many people had returned to their home towns to celebrate with their families, but it gave us a chance to explore without the regular chaos of the city.

First we visited one of the ancient palaces and gardens, making a huge natural park in the city centre. The buildings were impressive and it was a great place to really feel like we were in Asia, although David was melting in the summer heat!

We visited the local market where we had some food (it tasted nice but probably wasn't the smartest idea ever!) - we were surprised at how un-touristic it was .. not a postcard in sight. Then we discovered Myeong Dong, the shopping / eating / going out district which felt more like Europe than Asia - save for the dried fish and fried octopus tentacles for sale at regular intervals along the market.

We finished off a busy day with a trip up the cable car to the N Seoul Tower - and after a long wait to get to the top, we discovered that the tower was already closed. We still had a decent view from the bottom, and hopefully we can return on a clearer day to be able to see further.

Our second day was spent through a return to the market, visiting a fancy department store to see which western products we would be able to acquire on subsequent trips to Seoul, then wandering through the Gangnam area, trying to understand the Gangnam Style a little better.

Overall we were very impressed with the ease of use of the subway and the easy trip from Gangneung. Hopefully we will be able to return at regular intervals to explore further.

item.title: Gangneung
item.description:
This weekend was Chuseok in South Korea. Monday, Tuesday and Wednesday were bank holidays, which gave us some time to visit.

On the weekend, we walked in the city of Gangneung and to the beach. Gangneung is on the coast and has several beaches that are very nice. On top of that, the weather was great (sunny and 27 degrees), so I went for a swim in the warm water.

The path along the beach is covered by pine trees, a symbol of Gangneung. Sometimes, we can see a bunker, reminding us that South Korea and North Korea are (technically) still at war, but they don't seem to be used a lot.

We can already see signs that Gangneung will host part of the 2018 Winter Olympics, as several Olympic rings are displayed around the city.

One last word about coffee: it is very popular here, and can be drunk cold. In every supermarket or convenience stores, small bottles or cans of coffee are displayed in fridges alongside fruit juices. It is actually better than I expected.

item.title: First post
item.description:
Here we go, we have moved to Korea.

It has already been a week, and even if we haven't had much time to explore, we had the time to enjoy a good range of different Korean food, and visit the city a bit.

We spent the first week in Alpensia, in PyongChang. This is a ski resort that looks very similar to the ones I kow in France, except for the Korean characters on the sign posts. There are not a lot of summer activities, but the mountains are very green. Next week, we are moving to Gangneung, a coastal city.

Below is a selection of pictures illustrating different aspect of our discoveries so far.
